text: If it’s used right, it makes sense. If you check the first example here for instance: <https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0635/|https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0635/>

attachments.text: The official home of the Python Programming Language

elements.text: If it’s used right, it makes sense. If you check the first example here for instance:
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0635/

text: One of the symptoms is here: ”The match and case keywords are soft keywords, i.e. they are not reserved words in other grammatical contexts (including at the start of a line if there is no colon where expected). This implies that they are recognized as keywords when part of a match statement or case block only, and are allowed to be used in all other contexts as variable or argument names.”

elements.text: One of the symptoms is here: ”The match and case keywords are soft keywords, i.e. they are not reserved words in other grammatical contexts (including at the start of a line if there is no colon where expected). This implies that they are recognized as keywords when part of a match statement or case block only, and are allowed to be used in all other contexts as variable or argument names.”

text: I think the disease is that the language has become too complicated to add new features.

text: I believe this is likely to hit most languages eventually.

elements.text: I believe this is likely to hit most languages eventually.

text:
Is there a clean way to do this in Julia?
```match x:
    case host, port:
        mode = "http"
    case host, port, mode:
        pass
    # Etc.```

elements.text: Is there a clean way to do this in Julia?

match x:
    case host, port:
        mode = "http"
    case host, port, mode:
        pass
    # Etc.

text: huh indeed it's pretty cool, looks like the only problem comes from the misinterpretation as a switch?

elements.text: huh indeed it's pretty cool, looks like the only problem comes from the misinterpretation as a switch?

text:
That is equivalent to this 
```if isinstance(x, tuple) and len(x) == 2:
    host, port = x
    mode = "http"
elif isinstance(x, tuple) and len(x) == 3:
    host, port, mode = x
# Etc.```
